messageBody:
JBR wrote:
> Yes, I suppose that's one condition under which it would
> work: if Java is used as a scripting language to test the
> application from the outside. Where I have seen it fail
> miserably and repeatedly is when "external" testers
> (converted programmers) try to write object-level tests for
> code they're not permitted to or don't know how to change.
>
> You're the first person to tell me they had this working, so
> I'd never thought it possible before. I'm glad to hear it's
> working for you, and I'll keep it in mind the next time this
> discussion rolls around.

Hmm, we've been doing this for well over a year now.
It's definitely possible! JUnit has so many of the
tools that you'd normally need to build from scratch
if you want a new system testing framework that it
made a lot of sense to reuse all that stuff. For in-
stance, test runners (Eclipse and ant), pass/fail
reporting, suites, all the JUnit add-ons, etc.


Todd.
